A Dense Initialization for Limited-Memory Quasi-Newton Methods

Johannes Brust jbrust@ucmerced.edu Applied Mathematics, University of California, Merced, Merced, CA 95343 ,¬† Oleg Burdakov oleg.burdakov@liu.se Department of Mathematics, Link√∂ping University, SE-581 83 Link√∂ping, Sweden ,¬† Jennifer B. Erway erwayjb@wfu.edu Department of Mathematics, Wake Forest University, Winston-Salem, NC 27109 ¬†and¬† Roummel F. Marcia rmarcia@ucmerced.edu Applied Mathematics, University of California, Merced, Merced, CA 95343
Abstract.

We consider a family of dense initializations for limited-memory quasi-Newton methods. The proposed initialization exploits an eigendecomposition-based separation of the full space into two complementary subspaces, assigning a different initialization parameter to each subspace. This family of dense initializations is proposed in the context of a limited-memory Broyden-Fletcher-Goldfarb-Shanno (L-BFGS) trust-region method that makes use of a shape-changing norm to define each subproblem. As with L-BFGS methods that traditionally use diagonal initialization, the dense initialization and the sequence of generated quasi-Newton matrices are never explicitly formed. Numerical experiments on the CUTEst test set suggest that this initialization together with the shape-changing trust-region method outperforms other L-BFGS methods for solving general nonconvex unconstrained optimization problems. While this dense initialization is proposed in the context of a special trust-region method, it has broad applications for more general quasi-Newton trust-region and line search methods. In fact, this initialization is suitable for use with any quasi-Newton update that admits a compact representation and, in particular, any member of the Broyden class of updates.

Key words and phrases:
Large-scale nonlinear optimization, limited-memory quasi-Newton methods, trust-region methods, quasi-Newton matrices, shape-changing norm

R.¬†F. Marcia is supported in part by National Science Foundation grants CMMI-1333326 and IIS-1741490

1. Introduction

In this paper we propose a new dense initialization for quasi-Newton methods to solve problems of the form

¬†minimize¬†x‚àà‚Ñún‚Äãf‚Äã(x),ùë•superscriptùëõ¬†minimize¬†ùëìùë•\underset{x\in\Re^{n}}{\text{ minimize }}f(x),

where f:‚Ñún‚Üí‚Ñú:ùëì‚Üísuperscriptùëõf:\Re^{n}\rightarrow\Re is at least a continuously differentiable function, which is not necessarily convex. The dense initialization matrix is designed to be updated each time a new quasi-Newton pair is computed (i.e., as often as once an iteration); however, in order to retain the efficiency of limited-memory quasi-Newton methods, the dense initialization matrix and the generated sequence of quasi-Newton matrices are not explicitly formed. This proposed initialization makes use of a partial eigendecomposition of these matrices for separating ‚Ñúnsuperscriptùëõ\Re^{n} into two orthogonal subspaces ‚Äì one for which there is approximate curvature information and the other for which there is no reliable curvature information. This initialization has broad applications for general quasi-Newton trust-region and line search methods. In fact, this work can be applied to any quasi-Newton method that uses an update with a compact representation, which includes any member of the Broyden class of updates. For this paper, we explore its use in one specific algorithm; in particular we consider a limited-memory Broyden-Fletcher-Goldfarb-Shanno (L-BFGS) trust-region method where each subproblem is defined using a shape-changing norm¬†[3]. The reason for this choice is that the dense initialization is naturally well-suited for solving L-BFGS trust-region subproblems defined by this norm. Numerical results on the CUTEst test set suggest that the dense initialization outperforms other L-BFGS methods.

The BFGS update is the most widely-used quasi-Newton update for large-scale optimization; it is defined by the recursion formula

Bk+1=Bk‚àí1skT‚ÄãBk‚Äãsk‚ÄãBk‚Äãsk‚ÄãskT‚ÄãBk+1skT‚Äãyk‚Äãyk‚ÄãykT,subscriptùêµùëò1subscriptùêµùëò1subscriptsuperscriptùë†ùëáùëòsubscriptùêµùëòsubscriptùë†ùëòsubscriptùêµùëòsubscriptùë†ùëòsuperscriptsubscriptùë†ùëòùëásubscriptùêµùëò1subscriptsuperscriptùë†ùëáùëòsubscriptùë¶ùëòsubscriptùë¶ùëòsubscriptsuperscriptùë¶ùëáùëòB_{k+1}=B_{k}-\frac{1}{s^{T}_{k}B_{k}s_{k}}B_{k}s_{k}s_{k}^{T}B_{k}+\frac{1}{s^{T}_{k}y_{k}}y_{k}y^{T}_{k}, (1)

where

sk‚Äã=‚ñ≥xk+1‚àíxk¬†and¬†yk‚Äã=‚ñ≥‚àáf‚Äã(xk+1)‚àí‚àáf‚Äã(xk),subscriptùë†ùëòsuperscript‚ñ≥subscriptùë•ùëò1subscriptùë•ùëò¬†and¬†subscriptùë¶ùëòsuperscript‚ñ≥‚àáùëìsubscriptùë•ùëò1‚àáùëìsubscriptùë•ùëòs_{k}\mathop{\,{\scriptstyle\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\triangle}}{{=}}}}\,x_{k+1}-x_{k}\quad\text{ and }\quad y_{k}\mathop{\,{\scriptstyle\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\triangle}}{{=}}}}\,\nabla f(x_{k+1})-\nabla f(x_{k}), (2)

and B0‚àà‚Ñún√ónsubscriptùêµ0superscriptùëõùëõB_{0}\in\Re^{n\times n} is a suitably-chosen initial matrix. This rank-two update to BksubscriptùêµùëòB_{k} preserves positive definiteness when skT‚Äãyk>0subscriptsuperscriptùë†ùëáùëòsubscriptùë¶ùëò0s^{T}_{k}y_{k}>0.

L-BFGS is a limited-memory variant of BFGS that only stores a predetermined number, mùëöm, of the most recently-computed pairs {si,yi}subscriptùë†ùëñsubscriptùë¶ùëñ\{s_{i},y_{i}\} where m‚â™nmuch-less-thanùëöùëõm\ll n. (Typically, m‚àà[3,7]ùëö37m\in[3,7] (see, e.g.,¬†[5]).) Together with an intial matrix B0subscriptùêµ0B_{0} that depends on kùëòk, these pairs are used to compute BksubscriptùêµùëòB_{k}. For notational simplicity, we drop the dependence of the initial matrix on kùëòk and simply denote it as B0subscriptùêµ0B_{0}. This limitation on the number of stored pairs allows for a practical implementation of the BFGS method for large-scale optimization.

There are several desirable properties for picking the initial matrix B0subscriptùêµ0B_{0}. First, in order for the sequence {Bk}subscriptùêµùëò\{B_{k}\} generated by (1) to be symmetric and positive definite, it is necessary that B0subscriptùêµ0B_{0} is symmetric and positive definite. Second, it is desirable for B0subscriptùêµ0B_{0} to be easily invertible so that solving linear systems with any matrix in the sequence is computable using the so-called ‚Äútwo-loop recursion‚Äù¬†[5] or other recursive formulas for Bk‚àí1superscriptsubscriptùêµùëò1B_{k}^{-1} (for an overview of other available methods see¬†[9]). For these reasons, B0subscriptùêµ0B_{0} is often chosen to be a scalar multiple of the identity matrix, i.e.,

B0=Œ≥k‚ÄãI,withŒ≥k>0.formulae-sequencesubscriptùêµ0subscriptùõæùëòùêºwithsubscriptùõæùëò0B_{0}=\gamma_{k}I,\quad\text{with}\quad\gamma_{k}>0. (3)

For BFGS matrices, the conventional choice for the initialization parameter Œ≥ksubscriptùõæùëò\gamma_{k} is

Œ≥k=ykT‚ÄãykskT‚Äãyk,subscriptùõæùëòsubscriptsuperscriptùë¶ùëáùëòsubscriptùë¶ùëòsubscriptsuperscriptùë†ùëáùëòsubscriptùë¶ùëò\gamma_{k}=\frac{y^{T}_{k}y_{k}}{s^{T}_{k}y_{k}}, (4)

which can be viewed as a spectral estimate for ‚àá2f‚Äã(xk)superscript‚àá2ùëìsubscriptùë•ùëò\nabla^{2}f(x_{k})¬†[13]. (This choice was originally proposed in¬†[14] using a derivation based on optimal conditioning.) It is worth noting that this choice of Œ≥ksubscriptùõæùëò\gamma_{k} can also be derived as the minimizer of the scalar minimization problem

Œ≥k=¬†argmin¬†ùõæ‚Äã‚ÄñB0‚àí1‚Äãyk‚àísk‚Äñ22,subscriptùõæùëòùõæ¬†argmin¬†subscriptsuperscriptnormsubscriptsuperscriptùêµ10subscriptùë¶ùëòsubscriptùë†ùëò22\gamma_{k}=\underset{\gamma}{\text{ argmin }}\left\|B^{-1}_{0}y_{k}-s_{k}\right\|^{2}_{2}, (5)

where B0‚àí1=Œ≥‚àí1‚ÄãIsubscriptsuperscriptùêµ10superscriptùõæ1ùêºB^{-1}_{0}=\gamma^{-1}I. For numerical studies on this choice of initialization, see, e.g., the references listed within¬†[4].


In this paper, we consider a specific dense initialization in lieu of the usual diagonal initialization. The aforementioned separation of ‚Ñúnsuperscriptùëõ\Re^{n} into two orthogonal subspaces allows for different initialization parameters to be used to estimate the curvature of the underlying function in these subspaces. In one space (the space spanned by the most recent updates {si,yi}subscriptùë†ùëñsubscriptùë¶ùëñ\{s_{i},y_{i}\} with k‚àím‚â§i‚â§k‚àí1ùëòùëöùëñùëò1k-m\leq i\leq k-1), estimates of the curvature of the underlying function are available, and thus, one initialization parameter can be set using this information. However, in its orthogonal complement, curvature information is not available. Therefore, if the component of the trial step in the orthogonal subspace is (relatively) too large, the predictive quality of the whole trial step is expected to deteriorate. As a result, the trust-region radius might be reduced, despite the fact that the predictive quality of the component in the aforementioned small subspace may be sufficiently good. Separating the whole space into these two subspaces allows users to treat each subspace differently. An alternative view of this initialization is that it makes use of two spectral estimates of ‚àá2f‚Äã(xk)superscript‚àá2ùëìsubscriptùë•ùëò\nabla^{2}f(x_{k}). Finally, the proposed initialization also allows for efficiently solving and computing products with the resulting quasi-Newton matrices.

The paper is organized in five sections. In Section 2, we review properties of L-BFGS matrices arising from their special recursive structure as well as overview the shape-changing trust-region method to be used in this paper. In Section 3, we present the proposed trust-region method that uses a shape-changing norm together with a dense initialization matrix. While this dense initialization is presented in one specific context, it can be used in combination with any quasi-Newton update that admits a so-called compact representation. Numerical experiments comparing this method with other combinations of initializations and L-BFGS methods are reported in Section 4, and concluding remarks are found in Section 5.

2. Background

In this section, we overview the compact formulation for L-BFGS matrices and how to efficiently compute a partial eigendecomposition. Finally, we review the shape-changing trust-region method considered in this paper.

2.1. The compact representation

The special structure of the recursion formula for L-BFGS matrices admits a so-called compact representation¬†[5], which is overviewed in this section.

Using the mùëöm most recently computed pairs {sj}subscriptùë†ùëó\{s_{j}\} and {yj}subscriptùë¶ùëó\{y_{j}\} given in (2), we define the following matrices

Sk‚Äã=‚ñ≥[sk‚àím‚Äã‚ãØ‚Äãsk‚àí1]¬†and¬†Yk‚Äã=‚ñ≥[yk‚àím‚Äã‚ãØ‚Äãyk‚àí1].subscriptùëÜùëòsuperscript‚ñ≥delimited-[]subscriptùë†ùëòùëö‚ãØsubscriptùë†ùëò1¬†and¬†subscriptùëåùëòsuperscript‚ñ≥delimited-[]subscriptùë¶ùëòùëö‚ãØsubscriptùë¶ùëò1S_{k}\mathop{\,{\scriptstyle\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\triangle}}{{=}}}}\,\left[s_{k-m}\,\,\cdots\,\,s_{k-1}\right]\quad\text{ and }\quad Y_{k}\mathop{\,{\scriptstyle\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\triangle}}{{=}}}}\,\left[y_{k-m}\,\,\cdots\,\,y_{k-1}\right].

With LksubscriptùêøùëòL_{k} taken to be the strictly lower triangular part of the matrix of SkT‚ÄãYksubscriptsuperscriptùëÜùëáùëòsubscriptùëåùëòS^{T}_{k}Y_{k}, and Dksubscriptùê∑ùëòD_{k} defined as the diagonal of SkT‚ÄãYksubscriptsuperscriptùëÜùëáùëòsubscriptùëåùëòS^{T}_{k}Y_{k}, the compact representation of an L-BFGS matrix is

Bk=B0+Œ®k‚ÄãMk‚ÄãŒ®kT,subscriptùêµùëòsubscriptùêµ0subscriptŒ®ùëòsubscriptùëÄùëòsubscriptsuperscriptŒ®ùëáùëòB_{k}=B_{0}+\Psi_{k}M_{k}\Psi^{T}_{k}, (6)

where

Œ®k‚Äã=‚ñ≥[B0‚ÄãSk‚ÄãYk]andMk‚Äã=‚ñ≥‚àí[SkT‚ÄãB0‚ÄãSkLkLkT‚àíDk]‚àí1subscriptŒ®ùëòsuperscript‚ñ≥delimited-[]subscriptùêµ0subscriptùëÜùëòsubscriptùëåùëòandsubscriptùëÄùëòsuperscript‚ñ≥superscriptdelimited-[]subscriptsuperscriptùëÜùëáùëòsubscriptùêµ0subscriptùëÜùëòsubscriptùêøùëòsubscriptsuperscriptùêøùëáùëòsubscriptùê∑ùëò1\Psi_{k}\mathop{\,{\scriptstyle\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\triangle}}{{=}}}}\,\left[B_{0}S_{k}\,\,Y_{k}\right]\quad\text{and}\quad M_{k}\mathop{\,{\scriptstyle\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\triangle}}{{=}}}}\,-\left[\begin{array}[]{c c}S^{T}_{k}B_{0}S_{k}&L_{k}\\ L^{T}_{k}&-D_{k}\end{array}\right]^{-1} (7)

(see¬†[5] for details). Note that Œ®k‚àà‚Ñún√ó2‚ÄãmsubscriptŒ®ùëòsuperscriptùëõ2ùëö\Psi_{k}\in\Re^{n\times 2m}, and Mk‚àà‚Ñú2‚Äãm√ó2‚ÄãmsubscriptùëÄùëòsuperscript2ùëö2ùëöM_{k}\in\Re^{2m\times 2m} is invertible provided siT‚Äãyi>0superscriptsubscriptùë†ùëñùëásubscriptùë¶ùëñ0s_{i}^{T}y_{i}>0 for all iùëñi¬†[5, Theorem 2.3]. An advantage of the compact representation is that if B0subscriptùêµ0B_{0} is chosen to be a multiple of the identity, then computing products with BksubscriptùêµùëòB_{k} or solving linear systems with BksubscriptùêµùëòB_{k} can be done efficiently¬†[9, 12].

It should be noted that L-BFGS matrices are just one member of the Broyden class of matrices (see, e.g.,¬†[13]), and in fact every member of the Broyden class of matrices admits a compact representation¬†[6, 8, 12].

2.2. Partial eigendecomposition of BksubscriptùêµùëòB_{k}

If B0subscriptùêµ0B_{0} is taken to be a multiple of the identity matrix, then the partial eigendecomposition of BksubscriptùêµùëòB_{k} can be computed efficiently from the compact representation (6) using either a partial QR decomposition¬†[3] or a partial singular value decomposition (SVD)¬†[11]. Below, we review the approach that uses the QR decomposition, and we assume that Œ®ksubscriptŒ®ùëò\Psi_{k} has rank r=2‚Äãmùëü2ùëör=2m. (For the rank-deficient case, see the techniques found in [3].)

2.2.1. Practical computations

Using the above method yields the eigenvalues of BksubscriptùêµùëòB_{k} as well as the ability to compute products with P‚à•subscriptùëÉparallel-toP_{\parallel}. Formula (8) indicates that QùëÑQ is not required to be explicitly formed in order to compute products with P‚à•subscriptùëÉparallel-toP_{\parallel}. For this reason, it is desirable to avoid forming QùëÑQ by computing only RùëÖR via the Cholesky factorization of Œ®kT‚ÄãŒ®ksubscriptsuperscriptŒ®ùëáùëòsubscriptŒ®ùëò\Psi^{T}_{k}\Psi_{k}, i.e., Œ®kT‚ÄãŒ®k=RT‚ÄãRsubscriptsuperscriptŒ®ùëáùëòsubscriptŒ®ùëòsuperscriptùëÖùëáùëÖ\Psi^{T}_{k}\Psi_{k}=R^{T}R (see¬†[3]).

At an additional expense, the eigenvectors stored in the columns of P‚à•subscriptùëÉparallel-toP_{\parallel} may be formed and stored. For the shape-changing trust-region method used in this paper, it is not required to store P‚à•subscriptùëÉparallel-toP_{\parallel}. In contrast, the matrix P‚üÇsubscriptùëÉperpendicular-toP_{\perp} is prohibitively expensive to form. It turns out that for this work it is only necessary to be able to compute projections into the subspace P‚üÇ‚ÄãP‚üÇTsubscriptùëÉperpendicular-tosuperscriptsubscriptùëÉperpendicular-toùëáP_{\perp}P_{\perp}^{T}, which can be done using the identity

P‚üÇ‚ÄãP‚üÇT=I‚àíP‚à•‚ÄãP‚à•T.subscriptùëÉperpendicular-tosubscriptsuperscriptùëÉùëáperpendicular-toùêºsubscriptùëÉparallel-tosubscriptsuperscriptùëÉùëáparallel-toP_{\perp}P^{T}_{\perp}=I-P_{\parallel}P^{T}_{\parallel}. (12)

2.3. A shape-changing L-BFGS trust-region method

Generally speaking, at the kùëòkth step of a trust-region method, a search direction is computed by approximately solving the trust-region subproblem

p‚àó=¬†argmin¬†‚Äñp‚Äñ‚â§Œîk‚ÄãQ‚Äã(p)‚Äã=‚ñ≥gkT‚Äãp+12‚ÄãpT‚ÄãBk‚Äãp,superscriptùëùnormùëùsubscriptŒîùëò¬†argmin¬†ùëÑùëùsuperscript‚ñ≥subscriptsuperscriptùëîùëáùëòùëù12superscriptùëùùëásubscriptùêµùëòùëùp^{*}=\underset{\left\|p\right\|\leq{\Delta_{k}}}{\text{ argmin }}Q(p)\mathop{\,{\scriptstyle\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\triangle}}{{=}}}}\,g^{T}_{k}p+\frac{1}{2}p^{T}B_{k}p, (13)

where gk‚Äã=‚ñ≥‚àáf‚Äã(xk)subscriptùëîùëòsuperscript‚ñ≥‚àáùëìsubscriptùë•ùëòg_{k}\mathop{\,{\scriptstyle\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\triangle}}{{=}}}}\,\nabla f(x_{k}), Bk‚âà‚àá2f‚Äã(xk)subscriptùêµùëòsuperscript‚àá2ùëìsubscriptùë•ùëòB_{k}\approx\nabla^{2}f(x_{k}), and Œîk>0subscriptŒîùëò0\Delta_{k}>0 is the trust-region radius. When second derivatives are unavailable or computationally too expensive to compute, approximations using gradient information may be preferred. Not only do quasi-Newton matrices use only gradient and function information, but in the large-scale case, these Hessian approximations are never stored; instead, a recursive formula or methods that avoid explicitly forming BksubscriptùêµùëòB_{k} may be used to compute matrix-vector products with the approximate Hessians or their inverses¬†[5, 8, 9, 12].

Consider the trust-region subproblem defined by the shape-changing infinity norm:

¬†minimize¬†‚Äñp‚ÄñP,‚àû‚â§Œîk‚ÄãQ‚Äã(p)=gkT‚Äãp+12‚ÄãpT‚ÄãBk‚Äãp,subscriptnormùëùùëÉsubscriptŒîùëò¬†minimize¬†ùëÑùëùsubscriptsuperscriptùëîùëáùëòùëù12superscriptùëùùëásubscriptùêµùëòùëù\underset{\left\|p\right\|_{P,\infty}\leq{\Delta_{k}}}{\text{ minimize }}Q(p)=g^{T}_{k}p+\frac{1}{2}p^{T}B_{k}p, (14)

where

‚Äñp‚ÄñP,‚àû‚Äã=‚ñ≥max‚Äã(‚ÄñP‚à•T‚Äãp‚Äñ‚àû,‚ÄñP‚üÇT‚Äãp‚Äñ2)subscriptnormùëùùëÉsuperscript‚ñ≥maxsubscriptnormsubscriptsuperscriptùëÉùëáparallel-toùëùsubscriptnormsubscriptsuperscriptùëÉùëáperpendicular-toùëù2\left\|p\right\|_{P,\infty}\mathop{\,{\scriptstyle\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\triangle}}{{=}}}}\,\text{max}\left(\|P^{T}_{\parallel}p\|_{\infty},\|P^{T}_{\perp}p\|_{2}\right) (15)

and P‚à•subscriptùëÉparallel-toP_{\parallel} and P‚üÇsubscriptùëÉperpendicular-toP_{\perp} are given in (11). Note that the ratio ‚Äñp‚Äñ2/‚Äñp‚ÄñP,‚àûsubscriptnormùëù2subscriptnormùëùùëÉ\|p\|_{2}/\|p\|_{P,\infty} does not depend on nùëõn and only moderately depends on rùëür. (In particular, 1‚â§‚Äñp‚Äñ2/‚Äñp‚ÄñP,‚àû‚â§r+11subscriptnormùëù2subscriptnormùëùùëÉùëü11\leq\|p\|_{2}/\|p\|_{P,\infty}\leq\sqrt{r+1}.) Because this norm depends on the eigenvectors of BksubscriptùêµùëòB_{k}, the shape of the trust region changes each time the quasi-Newton matrix is updated, which is possibly every iteration of a trust-region method. (See¬†[3] for more details and other properties of this norm.) The motivation for this choice of norm is that the the trust-region subproblem (14) decouples into two separate problems for which closed-form solutions exist.

We now review the closed-form solution to (14), as detailed in¬†[3]. Let

where the latter term is computed using (12). Additional simplifications yield the following expression for p‚àósuperscriptùëùp^{*}:

p‚àó=Œ≤‚Äãg+P‚à•‚Äã(v‚à•‚àó‚àíŒ≤‚Äãg‚à•).superscriptùëùùõΩùëîsubscriptùëÉparallel-tosuperscriptsubscriptùë£parallel-toùõΩsubscriptùëîparallel-top^{*}=\beta g+P_{\parallel}(v_{\parallel}^{*}-\beta g_{\parallel}). (23)

The overall cost of computing the solution to (14) is comparable to that of using the Euclidean norm (see¬†[3]). The main advantage of using the shape-changing norm (15) is that the solution p‚àósuperscriptùëùp^{*} in (23) has a closed-form expression.

3. The Proposed Method

In this section, we present a new dense initialization and demonstrate how it is naturally well-suited for trust-region methods defined by the shape-changing infinity norm. Finally, we present a full trust-region algorithm that uses the dense initialization, consider its computational cost, and prove global convergence.

3.1. Dense initial matrix B^0subscript^ùêµ0\widehat{B}_{0}

In this section, we propose a new dense initialization for quasi-Newton methods. Importantly, in order to retain the efficiency of quasi-Newton methods the dense initialization matrix and subsequently updated quasi-Newton matrices are never explicitly formed. This initialization can be used with any quasi-Newton update for which there is a compact representation; however, for simplicity, we continue to refer to the BFGS update throughout this section. For notational purposes, we use the initial matrix B0subscriptùêµ0B_{0} to represent the usual initialization and B^0subscript^ùêµ0\widehat{B}_{0} to denote the proposed dense initialization. Similarly, {Bk}subscriptùêµùëò\{B_{k}\} and {B^k}subscript^ùêµùëò\{\widehat{B}_{k}\} will be used to denote the sequences of matrices obtained using the initializations B0subscriptùêµ0B_{0} and B^0subscript^ùêµ0\widehat{B}_{0}, respectively.

Our goal in choosing an alternative initialization is four-fold: (i) to be able to treat subspaces differently depending on whether curvature information is available or not, (ii) to preserve properties of symmetry and positive-definiteness, (iii) to be able to efficiently compute products with the resulting quasi-Newton matrices, and (iv) to be able to efficiently solve linear systems involving the resulting quasi-Newton matrices. The initialization proposed in this paper leans upon two different parameter choices that can be viewed as an estimate of the curvature of ‚àá2f‚Äã(xk)superscript‚àá2ùëìsubscriptùë•ùëò\nabla^{2}f(x_{k}) in two subspaces: one spanned by the columns of P‚à•subscriptùëÉparallel-toP_{\parallel} and another spanned by the columns of P‚üÇsubscriptùëÉperpendicular-toP_{\perp}.

The usual initialization for a BFGS matrix BksubscriptùêµùëòB_{k} is B0=Œ≥k‚ÄãIsubscriptùêµ0subscriptùõæùëòùêºB_{0}=\gamma_{k}I, where Œ≥k>0subscriptùõæùëò0\gamma_{k}>0. Note that this initialization is equivalent to

B0=Œ≥k‚ÄãP‚ÄãPT=Œ≥k‚ÄãP‚à•‚ÄãP‚à•T+Œ≥k‚ÄãP‚üÇ‚ÄãP‚üÇT.subscriptùêµ0subscriptùõæùëòùëÉsuperscriptùëÉùëásubscriptùõæùëòsubscriptùëÉparallel-tosubscriptsuperscriptùëÉùëáparallel-tosubscriptùõæùëòsubscriptùëÉperpendicular-tosubscriptsuperscriptùëÉùëáperpendicular-toB_{0}=\gamma_{k}PP^{T}=\gamma_{k}P_{\parallel}P^{T}_{\parallel}+\gamma_{k}P_{\perp}P^{T}_{\perp}.

In contrast, for a given Œ≥k,Œ≥k‚üÇ‚àà‚Ñúsubscriptùõæùëòsubscriptsuperscriptùõæperpendicular-toùëò\gamma_{k},\gamma^{\perp}_{k}\in\Re, consider the following symmetric, and in general, dense initialization matrix:

B^0=Œ≥k‚ÄãP‚à•‚ÄãP‚à•T+Œ≥k‚üÇ‚ÄãP‚üÇ‚ÄãP‚üÇT,subscript^ùêµ0subscriptùõæùëòsubscriptùëÉparallel-tosubscriptsuperscriptùëÉùëáparallel-tosubscriptsuperscriptùõæperpendicular-toùëòsubscriptùëÉperpendicular-tosubscriptsuperscriptùëÉùëáperpendicular-to\widehat{B}_{0}=\gamma_{k}P_{\parallel}P^{T}_{\parallel}+\gamma^{\perp}_{k}P_{\perp}P^{T}_{\perp}, (24)

where P‚à•subscriptùëÉparallel-toP_{\parallel} and P‚üÇsubscriptùëÉperpendicular-toP_{\perp} are the matrices of eigenvectors defined in Section¬†2.2. We now derive the eigendecomposition of B^ksubscript^ùêµùëò\widehat{B}_{k}.

Theorem 1.

Let B^0subscript^ùêµ0\widehat{B}_{0} be defined as in (24). Then B^ksubscript^ùêµùëò\widehat{B}_{k} generated using (1) has the eigendecomposition

B^k=[P‚à•‚ÄãP‚üÇ]‚Äã[Œõ^+Œ≥k‚ÄãIrŒ≥k‚üÇ‚ÄãIn‚àír]‚Äã[P‚à•‚ÄãP‚üÇ]T,subscript^ùêµùëòdelimited-[]subscriptùëÉparallel-tosubscriptùëÉperpendicular-todelimited-[]^Œõsubscriptùõæùëòsubscriptùêºùëümissing-subexpressionmissing-subexpressionsubscriptsuperscriptùõæperpendicular-toùëòsubscriptùêºùëõùëüsuperscriptdelimited-[]subscriptùëÉparallel-tosubscriptùëÉperpendicular-toùëá\widehat{B}_{k}=\left[P_{\parallel}\,\,P_{\perp}\right]\left[\begin{array}[]{c c}\hat{\Lambda}+\gamma_{k}I_{r}&\\ &\gamma^{\perp}_{k}I_{n-r}\end{array}\right]\left[P_{\parallel}\,\,P_{\perp}\right]^{T}, (25)

where P‚à•,P‚üÇ,subscriptùëÉparallel-tosubscriptùëÉperpendicular-toP_{\parallel},P_{\perp}, and Œõ^^Œõ\hat{\Lambda} are given in (8), (11), and (9), respectively.

Proof.

First note that the columns of SksubscriptùëÜùëòS_{k} are in Range‚Äã(Œ®k)RangesubscriptŒ®ùëò\text{Range}(\Psi_{k}), where Œ®ksubscriptŒ®ùëò\Psi_{k} is defined in (7). It can be easily verified that (25) holds also for P‚à•subscriptùëÉparallel-toP_{\parallel} defined in¬†[3] for possibly rank-deficient Œ®ksubscriptŒ®ùëò\Psi_{k}. (Note that (8) applies only to the special case when Œ®ksubscriptŒ®ùëò\Psi_{k} is full-rank.)

Theorem¬†1 shows that the matrix B^ksubscript^ùêµùëò\widehat{B}_{k} that results from using the initialization (24) shares the same eigenvectors as BksubscriptùêµùëòB_{k}, generated using B0=Œ≥k‚ÄãIsubscriptùêµ0subscriptùõæùëòùêºB_{0}=\gamma_{k}I. Moreover, the eigenvalues corresponding to the eigenvectors stored in the columns of P‚à•subscriptùëÉparallel-toP_{\parallel} are the same for B^ksubscript^ùêµùëò\widehat{B}_{k} and BksubscriptùêµùëòB_{k}. The only difference in the eigendecompositions of B^ksubscript^ùêµùëò\widehat{B}_{k} and BksubscriptùêµùëòB_{k} is in the eigenvalues corresponding to the eigenvectors stored in the columns of P‚üÇsubscriptùëÉperpendicular-toP_{\perp}. This is summarized in the following corollary.

Corollary 1.

Suppose BksubscriptùêµùëòB_{k} is a BFGS matrix initialized with B0=Œ≥k‚ÄãIsubscriptùêµ0subscriptùõæùëòùêºB_{0}=\gamma_{k}I and B^ksubscript^ùêµùëò\widehat{B}_{k} is a BFGS matrix initialized with (24). Then BksubscriptùêµùëòB_{k} and B^ksubscript^ùêµùëò\widehat{B}_{k} have the same eigenvectors; moreover, these matrices have rùëür eigenvalues in common given by Œªi‚Äã=‚ñ≥Œª^i+Œ≥ksubscriptùúÜùëñsuperscript‚ñ≥subscript^ùúÜùëñsubscriptùõæùëò\lambda_{i}\mathop{\,{\scriptstyle\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\triangle}}{{=}}}}\,\hat{\lambda}_{i}+\gamma_{k} where Œõ^=diag‚Äã(Œª^1,‚Ä¶,Œª^r)^Œõdiagsubscript^ùúÜ1‚Ä¶subscript^ùúÜùëü\hat{\Lambda}=\text{diag}(\hat{\lambda}_{1},\ldots,\hat{\lambda}_{r}).

Proof.

The corollary follows immediately by comparing (10) with (25). ‚ñ°‚ñ°\square ‚àé

The results of Theorem¬†1 and Corollary¬†1 may seem surprising at first since every term in the compact representation ((6) and (7)) depends on the initialization; moreover, B^0subscript^ùêµ0\widehat{B}_{0} is, generally speaking, a dense matrix while B0subscriptùêµ0B_{0} is a diagonal matrix. However, viewed from the perspective of (24), the parameter Œ≥k‚üÇsubscriptsuperscriptùõæperpendicular-toùëò\gamma^{\perp}_{k} only plays a role in scaling the subspace spanned by the columns of P‚üÇsubscriptùëÉperpendicular-toP_{\perp}.

The initialization B^0subscript^ùêµ0\widehat{B}_{0} allows for two separate curvature approximations for the BFGS matrix: one in the space spanned by columns of P‚à•subscriptùëÉparallel-toP_{\parallel} and another in the space spanned by the columns of P‚üÇsubscriptùëÉperpendicular-toP_{\perp}. In the next subsection, we show that this initialization is naturally well-suited for solving trust-region subproblems defined by the shape-changing infinity norm.

3.2. The trust-region subproblem

Here we will show that the use of B^0subscript^ùêµ0\widehat{B}_{0} provides the same subproblem separability as B0subscriptùêµ0B_{0} does in the case of the shape-changing infinity norm.

For B^0subscript^ùêµ0\widehat{B}_{0} given by (24), consider the objective function of the trust-region subproblem (14) resulting from the change of variables (16):

where

which can computed as efficiently as the solution in (23) for conventional initial matrices since they differ only by the scalar (Œ≤^^ùõΩ\widehat{\beta} in (32) versus Œ≤ùõΩ\beta in (23)).

3.3. Determining the parameter Œ≥k‚üÇsubscriptsuperscriptùõæperpendicular-toùëò\gamma^{\perp}_{k}

The values Œ≥ksubscriptùõæùëò\gamma_{k} and Œ≥k‚üÇsubscriptsuperscriptùõæperpendicular-toùëò\gamma^{\perp}_{k} can be updated at each iteration. Since we have little information about the underlying function fùëìf in the subspace spanned by the columns of P‚üÇsubscriptùëÉperpendicular-toP_{\perp}, it is reasonable to make conservative (i.e., large) choices for Œ≥k‚üÇsubscriptsuperscriptùõæperpendicular-toùëò\gamma^{\perp}_{k}. Note that in the case that Œ≥k‚üÇ>0‚Äã¬†and¬†‚Äã‚Äñg‚üÇ‚Äñ2‚â§Œîk‚Äã|Œ≥k‚üÇ|subscriptsuperscriptùõæperpendicular-toùëò0¬†and¬†subscriptnormsubscriptùëîperpendicular-to2subscriptŒîùëòsubscriptsuperscriptùõæperpendicular-toùëò\gamma^{\perp}_{k}>0\text{ and }\left\|g_{\perp}\right\|_{2}\leq\Delta_{k}|\gamma^{\perp}_{k}|, the parameter Œ≥k‚üÇsubscriptsuperscriptùõæperpendicular-toùëò\gamma^{\perp}_{k} scales the solution v‚üÇ‚àósuperscriptsubscriptùë£perpendicular-tov_{\perp}^{*} (see 31); thus, large values of Œ≥k‚üÇsubscriptsuperscriptùõæperpendicular-toùëò\gamma^{\perp}_{k} will reduce these step lengths in the space spanned by P‚üÇsubscriptùëÉperpendicular-toP_{\perp}. Since the space P‚üÇsubscriptùëÉperpendicular-toP_{\perp} does not explicitly use information produced by past iterations, it seems desirable to choose Œ≥k‚üÇsubscriptsuperscriptùõæperpendicular-toùëò\gamma^{\perp}_{k} to be large. However, the larger that Œ≥k‚üÇsubscriptsuperscriptùõæperpendicular-toùëò\gamma^{\perp}_{k} is chosen, the closer v‚üÇ‚àósubscriptsuperscriptùë£perpendicular-tov^{*}_{\perp} will be to the zero vector. Also note that if Œ≥k‚üÇ<0subscriptsuperscriptùõæperpendicular-toùëò0\gamma^{\perp}_{k}<0 then the solution to the subproblem (29) will always lie on the boundary, and thus, the actual value of Œ≥k‚üÇsubscriptsuperscriptùõæperpendicular-toùëò\gamma^{\perp}_{k} becomes irrelevant. Moreover, for values Œ≥k‚üÇ<0subscriptsuperscriptùõæperpendicular-toùëò0\gamma^{\perp}_{k}<0, B^ksubscript^ùêµùëò\widehat{B}_{k} is not guaranteed to be positive definite. For these reasons, we suggest sufficiently large and positive values for Œ≥k‚üÇsubscriptsuperscriptùõæperpendicular-toùëò\gamma^{\perp}_{k} related to the curvature information gathered in Œ≥1,‚Ä¶,Œ≥ksubscriptùõæ1‚Ä¶subscriptùõæùëò\gamma_{1},\ldots,\gamma_{k}. Specific choices for Œ≥k‚üÇsubscriptsuperscriptùõæperpendicular-toùëò\gamma^{\perp}_{k} are presented in the numerical results section.

3.4. Implementation details

In this section, we describe how we incorporate the dense initialization within the existing LMTR algorithm¬†[3]. At the beginning of each iteration, the LMTR algorithm with dense initialization checks if the unconstrained minimizer (also known as the full quasi-Newton trial step),

pu‚àó=‚àíB^k‚àí1‚Äãgksuperscriptsubscriptùëùùë¢superscriptsubscript^ùêµùëò1subscriptùëîùëòp_{u}^{*}=-\hat{B}_{k}^{-1}g_{k} (33)

lies inside the trust region defined by the two-norm. Because our proposed method uses a dense initialization, the so-called ‚Äútwo-loop recursion‚Äù [6] is not applicable for computing the unconstrained minimizer pu‚àósuperscriptsubscriptùëùùë¢p_{u}^{*} in (33). ‚Äñpu‚àó‚Äñ2‚â§Œîksubscriptnormsuperscriptsubscriptùëùùë¢2subscriptŒîùëò\|p_{u}^{*}\|_{2}\leq\Delta_{k} (35)

is easily verified without explicitly forming pu‚àósuperscriptsubscriptùëùùë¢p_{u}^{*} using the identity

‚Äñpu‚àó‚Äñ22=gkT‚ÄãB^k‚àí2‚Äãgk=Œ≥k‚àí2‚Äã‚Äñgk‚Äñ2+2‚ÄãŒ≥k‚àí1‚ÄãukT‚ÄãM^k‚Äãuk+ukT‚ÄãM^k‚Äã(RkT‚ÄãRk)‚ÄãM^k‚Äãuk.superscriptsubscriptnormsuperscriptsubscriptùëùùë¢22superscriptsubscriptùëîùëòùëásuperscriptsubscript^ùêµùëò2subscriptùëîùëòsuperscriptsubscriptùõæùëò2superscriptnormsubscriptùëîùëò22superscriptsubscriptùõæùëò1superscriptsubscriptùë¢ùëòùëásubscript^ùëÄùëòsubscriptùë¢ùëòsuperscriptsubscriptùë¢ùëòùëásubscript^ùëÄùëòsuperscriptsubscriptùëÖùëòùëásubscriptùëÖùëòsubscript^ùëÄùëòsubscriptùë¢ùëò\|p_{u}^{*}\|_{2}^{2}=g_{k}^{T}\hat{B}_{k}^{-2}g_{k}=\gamma_{k}^{-2}\|g_{k}\|^{2}+2\gamma_{k}^{-1}u_{k}^{T}\hat{M}_{k}u_{k}+u_{k}^{T}\hat{M}_{k}(R_{k}^{T}R_{k})\hat{M}_{k}u_{k}. (36)

Here, as in the LMTR algorithm, the vector uk=VkT‚Äãgksubscriptùë¢ùëòsuperscriptsubscriptùëâùëòùëásubscriptùëîùëòu_{k}=V_{k}^{T}g_{k} and ‚Äñgk‚Äñ2superscriptnormsubscriptùëîùëò2\|g_{k}\|^{2} can be computed efficiently at each iteration (see [3] for details). Thus, the computational cost of ‚Äñpu‚àó‚Äñ2subscriptnormsuperscriptsubscriptùëùùë¢2\|p_{u}^{*}\|_{2} is low because (36) involves linear algebra operations in a small 2‚Äãm2ùëö2m-dimensional space, the most expensive of which are related to solving triangular systems with TksubscriptùëáùëòT_{k} and RksubscriptùëÖùëòR_{k}. These operations grow in proportion to m2superscriptùëö2m^{2} while the number of operations in (33)-(34) grows in proportion to m‚Äãnùëöùëõmn. Thus, the computational complexity ratio between using (36) and (33)-(34) is m2/(n‚Äãm)=m/n‚â™1superscriptùëö2ùëõùëöùëöùëõmuch-less-than1m^{2}/(nm)=m/n\ll 1 since we assume that m‚â™nmuch-less-thanùëöùëõm\ll n. The norm equivalence for the shape-changing infinity norm studied in¬†[3] guarantees that (35) implies that the inequality ‚Äñpu‚àó‚ÄñP,‚àû‚â§Œîksubscriptnormsuperscriptsubscriptùëùùë¢ùëÉsubscriptŒîùëò\|p_{u}^{*}\|_{P,\infty}\leq\Delta_{k} is satisfied; in this case, pu‚àósuperscriptsubscriptùëùùë¢p_{u}^{*} is the exact solution of the trust-region subproblem defined by the shape-changing infinity norm.

If (35) holds, the algorithm computes pu‚àósuperscriptsubscriptùëùùë¢p_{u}^{*} for generating the trial point xk+pu‚àósubscriptùë•ùëòsuperscriptsubscriptùëùùë¢x_{k}+p_{u}^{*}. It can be easily seen that the cost of computing pu‚àósuperscriptsubscriptùëùùë¢p_{u}^{*} is 4‚Äãm‚Äãn4ùëöùëõ4mn operations, i.e. it is the same as for computing search direction in the line search L-BFGS algorithm [6].

On the other hand, if (35) does not hold, then for producing a trial point, the partial eigendecomposition is computed, and the trust-region subproblem is decoupled and solved exactly as described in Section 3.2.

3.5. The algorithm and its properties

In Algorithm¬†1, we present a basic trust-region method that uses the proposed dense initialization. In this setting, we consider the computational cost of the proposed method, and we prove global convergence of the overall trust-region method. Since PùëÉP may change every iteration, the corresponding norm ‚à•‚ãÖ‚à•P,‚àû\|\cdot\|_{P,\infty} may change each iteration. Note that initially there are no stored quasi-Newton pairs {sj,yj}subscriptùë†ùëósubscriptùë¶ùëó\{s_{j},y_{j}\}. In this case, we assume P‚üÇ=InsubscriptùëÉperpendicular-tosubscriptùêºùëõP_{\perp}=I_{n} and P‚à•subscriptùëÉparallel-toP_{\parallel} does not exist, i.e., B^0=Œ≥0‚üÇ‚ÄãIsubscript^ùêµ0superscriptsubscriptùõæ0perpendicular-toùêº\hat{B}_{0}=\gamma_{0}^{\perp}I.

The only difference between Algorithm¬†1 and the LMTR algorithm in¬†[3] is the initialization matrix. Computationally speaking, the use of a dense initialization in lieu of a diagonal initialization plays out only in the computation of p‚àósuperscriptùëùp^{*} by (22). However, there is no computational cost difference: The cost of computing the value for Œ≤ùõΩ\beta using (31) in Algorithm¬†1 instead of (21) in the LMTR algorithm is the same. Thus, the dominant cost per iteration for both Algorithm¬†1 and the LMTR algorithm is 4‚Äãm‚Äãn4ùëöùëõ4mn operations (see¬†[3] for details). Note that this is the same cost-per-iteration as the line search L-BFGS algorithm¬†[5].

In the next result, we provide a global convergence result for Algorithm¬†1. This result is based on the convergence analysis presented in¬†[3].

Theorem 2.

Let f:Rn‚ÜíR:ùëì‚ÜísuperscriptùëÖùëõùëÖf:R^{n}\rightarrow R be twice-continuously differentiable and bounded below on RnsuperscriptùëÖùëõR^{n}. Suppose that there exists a scalar c1>0subscriptùëê10c_{1}>0 such that

‚Äñ‚àá2f‚Äã(x)‚Äñ‚â§c1,‚àÄx‚ààRn.formulae-sequencenormsuperscript‚àá2ùëìùë•subscriptùëê1for-allùë•superscriptùëÖùëõ\|\nabla^{2}f(x)\|\leq c_{1},\ \forall x\in R^{n}. (37)

Furthermore, suppose for B^0subscript^ùêµ0\hat{B}_{0} defined by (24), that there exists a positive scalar c2subscriptùëê2c_{2} such that

Œ≥k,Œ≥k‚üÇ‚àà(0,c2],‚àÄk‚â•0,formulae-sequencesubscriptùõæùëòsuperscriptsubscriptùõæùëòperpendicular-to0subscriptùëê2for-allùëò0\gamma_{k},\gamma_{k}^{\perp}\in(0,c_{2}],\ \forall k\geq 0, (38)

and there exists a scalar c3‚àà(0,1)subscriptùëê301c_{3}\in(0,1) such that the inequality

sjT‚Äãyj>c3‚Äã‚Äñsj‚Äñ‚Äã‚Äñyj‚Äñsuperscriptsubscriptùë†ùëóùëásubscriptùë¶ùëósubscriptùëê3normsubscriptùë†ùëónormsubscriptùë¶ùëós_{j}^{T}y_{j}>c_{3}\|s_{j}\|\|y_{j}\| (39)

holds for each quasi-Newton pair {sj,yj}subscriptùë†ùëósubscriptùë¶ùëó\{s_{j},y_{j}\}. Then, if the stopping criteria is suppressed, the infinite sequence {xk}subscriptùë•ùëò\{x_{k}\} generated by Algorithm¬†1 satisfies

limk‚Üí‚àû‚Äñ‚àáf‚Äã(xk)‚Äñ=0.subscript‚Üíùëònorm‚àáùëìsubscriptùë•ùëò0\lim_{k\rightarrow\infty}\|\nabla f(x_{k})\|=0. (40)
Proof.

From (38), we have ‚ÄñB^0‚Äñ‚â§c2,normsubscript^ùêµ0subscriptùëê2\|\hat{B}_{0}\|\leq c_{2}, which holds for each k‚â•0ùëò0k\geq 0. Then, by¬†[3, Lemma¬†3], there exists c4>0subscriptùëê40c_{4}>0 such that

‚ÄñB^k‚Äñ‚â§c4.normsubscript^ùêµùëòsubscriptùëê4\|\hat{B}_{k}\|\leq c_{4}.

Then, (40) follows from¬†[3, Theorem¬†1]. ‚ñ°‚ñ°\square ‚àé


In the following section, we consider Œ≥k‚üÇsuperscriptsubscriptùõæùëòperpendicular-to\gamma_{k}^{\perp} parameterized by two scalars, cùëêc and ŒªùúÜ\lambda:

Œ≥k‚üÇ‚Äã(c,Œª)=Œª‚Äãc‚ÄãŒ≥kmax+(1‚àíŒª)‚ÄãŒ≥k,superscriptsubscriptùõæùëòperpendicular-toùëêùúÜùúÜùëêsuperscriptsubscriptùõæùëò1ùúÜsubscriptùõæùëò\gamma_{k}^{\perp}(c,\lambda)=\lambda c\gamma_{k}^{\max}+(1-\lambda)\gamma_{k}, (41)

where c‚â•1,Œª‚àà[0,1]formulae-sequenceùëê1ùúÜ01c\geq 1,\lambda\in[0,1], and

Œ≥kmax‚Äã=‚ñ≥¬†max¬†‚ÄãŒ≥i1‚â§i‚â§k,superscriptsubscriptùõæùëòmaxsuperscript‚ñ≥1ùëñùëò¬†max¬†subscriptùõæùëñ\gamma_{k}^{\text{max}}\mathop{\,{\scriptstyle\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\triangle}}{{=}}}}\,\underset{1\leq i\leq k}{\text{ max }\gamma_{i}},

where Œ≥ksubscriptùõæùëò\gamma_{k} is taken to be the conventional initialization given by (4). (This choice for Œ≥k‚üÇsuperscriptsubscriptùõæùëòperpendicular-to\gamma_{k}^{\perp} will be further discussed in Section 4.) We now show that Algorithm 1 converges for these choices of Œ≥k‚üÇsuperscriptsubscriptùõæùëòperpendicular-to\gamma_{k}^{\perp}. Assuming that (37) and (39) hold, it remains to show that (38) holds for these choices of Œ≥k‚üÇsuperscriptsubscriptùõæùëòperpendicular-to\gamma_{k}^{\perp}. To see that (38) holds, notice that in this case,

Œ≥k=ykT‚ÄãykskT‚Äãyk‚â§ykT‚Äãykc3‚Äã‚Äñsk‚Äñ‚Äã‚Äñyk‚Äñ‚â§‚Äñyk‚Äñc3‚Äã‚Äñsk‚Äñ.subscriptùõæùëòsuperscriptsubscriptùë¶ùëòùëásubscriptùë¶ùëòsuperscriptsubscriptùë†ùëòùëásubscriptùë¶ùëòsuperscriptsubscriptùë¶ùëòùëásubscriptùë¶ùëòsubscriptùëê3normsubscriptùë†ùëònormsubscriptùë¶ùëònormsubscriptùë¶ùëòsubscriptùëê3normsubscriptùë†ùëò\gamma_{k}=\frac{y_{k}^{T}y_{k}}{s_{k}^{T}y_{k}}\leq\frac{y_{k}^{T}y_{k}}{c_{3}\|s_{k}\|\|y_{k}\|}\leq\frac{\|y_{k}\|}{c_{3}\|s_{k}\|}.

Substituting in for the definitions of yksubscriptùë¶ùëòy_{k} and sksubscriptùë†ùëòs_{k} yields that

Œ≥k‚â§‚Äñ‚àáf‚Äã(xk+1)‚àí‚àáf‚Äã(xk)‚Äñc3‚Äã‚Äñxk+1‚àíxk‚Äñ,subscriptùõæùëònorm‚àáùëìsubscriptùë•ùëò1‚àáùëìsubscriptùë•ùëòsubscriptùëê3normsubscriptùë•ùëò1subscriptùë•ùëò\gamma_{k}\leq\frac{\|\nabla f(x_{k+1})-\nabla f(x_{k})\|}{c_{3}\|x_{k+1}-x_{k}\|},

implying that (38) holds. Thus, Algorithm¬†1 converges for these choices for Œ≥k‚üÇsuperscriptsubscriptùõæùëòperpendicular-to\gamma_{k}^{\perp}.

4. Numerical Experiments

We performed numerical experiments using a Dell Precision T1700 machine with an Intel i5-4590 CPU at 3.303.303.30GHz X4 and 8GB RAM using MATLAB 2014a. The test set consisted of 65 large-scale (1000‚â§n‚â§100001000ùëõ100001000\leq n\leq 10000) CUTEst¬†[10] test problems, made up of all the test problems in¬†[3] plus an additional three (FMINSURF, PENALTY2, and TESTQUAD¬†[10]) since at least one of the methods in the experiments detailed below converged on one of these three problems. The same trust-region method and default parameters as in¬†[3, Algorithm 1] were used for the outer iteration. At most five quasi-Newton pairs {sk,yk}subscriptùë†ùëòsubscriptùë¶ùëò\{s_{k},y_{k}\} were stored, i.e., m=5ùëö5m=5. The relative stopping criterion was

‚Äñgk‚Äñ2‚â§œµ‚Äãmax‚Å°(1,‚Äñxk‚Äñ2),subscriptnormsubscriptùëîùëò2italic-œµ1subscriptnormsubscriptùë•ùëò2\left\|g_{k}\right\|_{2}\leq\epsilon\max\left(1,\left\|x_{k}\right\|_{2}\right),

with œµ=10‚àí10italic-œµsuperscript1010\epsilon=10^{-10}. The initial step, p0subscriptùëù0p_{0}, was determined by a backtracking line-search along the normalized steepest descent direction. To compute the partial eigendecomposition of BksubscriptùêµùëòB_{k}, we used the QR factorization instead of the SVD because the QR version outperformed the SVD version in numerical experiments not presented here. The rank of Œ®ksubscriptŒ®ùëò\Psi_{k} was estimated by the number of positive diagonal elements in the diagonal matrix of the LDLTsuperscriptLDLT\text{LDL}^{\text{T}} decomposition (or eigendecomposition of Œ®kT‚ÄãŒ®ksubscriptsuperscriptŒ®ùëáùëòsubscriptŒ®ùëò\Psi^{T}_{k}\Psi_{k}) that are larger than the threshold œµr=(10‚àí7)2subscriptitalic-œµùëüsuperscriptsuperscript1072\epsilon_{r}=(10^{-7})^{2}. (Note that the columns of Œ®ksubscriptŒ®ùëò\Psi_{k} are normalized.). We used the value c3=10‚àí8subscriptùëê3superscript108c_{3}=10^{-8} in (39) for testing whether to accept a new quasi-Newton pair.

We provide performance profiles (see [7]) for the number of iterations (iter) where the trust-region step is accepted and the average time (time) for each solver on the test set of problems. The performance metric, œÅùúå\rho, for the 65 problems is defined by

œÅs‚Äã(œÑ)=card‚Äã{p:œÄp,s‚â§œÑ}65andœÄp,s=tp,s¬†min¬†‚Äãtp,i1‚â§i‚â§S,formulae-sequencesubscriptùúåùë†ùúècardconditional-setùëùsubscriptùúãùëùùë†ùúè65andsubscriptùúãùëùùë†subscriptùë°ùëùùë†1ùëñùëÜ¬†min¬†subscriptùë°ùëùùëñ\rho_{s}(\tau)=\frac{\text{card}\left\{p:\pi_{p,s}\leq\tau\right\}}{65}\quad\text{and}\quad\pi_{p,s}=\frac{t_{p,s}}{\underset{1\leq i\leq S}{\text{ min }t_{p,i}}},

where tp,ssubscriptùë°ùëùùë†t_{p,s} is the ‚Äúoutput‚Äù (i.e., time or iterations) of ‚Äúsolver‚Äù sùë†s on problem pùëùp. Here SùëÜS denotes the total number of solvers for a given comparison. This metric measures the proportion of how close a given solver is to the best result. We observe as in [3] that the first runs significantly differ in time from the remaining runs, and thus, we ran each algorithm ten times on each problem, reporting the average of the final eight runs.


In this section, we present the following six types of experiments involving LMTR:

  1. (1)

    A comparison of results for different values of Œ≥k‚üÇ‚Äã(c,Œª)superscriptsubscriptùõæùëòperpendicular-toùëêùúÜ\gamma_{k}^{\perp}(c,\lambda).

  2. (2)

    Two versions of computing the full quasi-Newton trial step are compared. One version uses the dense initialization to compute pu‚àósuperscriptsubscriptùëùùë¢p_{u}^{*} as described in Section 3.4 (see (33)); the other uses the conventional initialization, i.e., pu‚àósuperscriptsubscriptùëùùë¢p_{u}^{*} is computed as pu‚àó=Bk‚àí1‚Äãgksuperscriptsubscriptùëùùë¢superscriptsubscriptùêµùëò1subscriptùëîùëòp_{u}^{*}=B_{k}^{-1}g_{k}. When the full quasi-Newton trial step is not accepted in any of the versions, the dense initialization is used for computing trial step by explicitly solving the trust-region subproblem (Section 3.2).

  3. (3)

    A comparison of LMTR together with a dense initialization and the line search L-BFGS method with the conventional initialization.

  4. (4)

    A comparison of LMTR with a dense initialization and L-BFGS-TR¬†[3], which computes a scaled quasi-Newton direction that lies inside a trust region. This method can be viewed as a hybrid line search and trust-region algorithm.

  5. (5)

    A comparison of the dense and conventional initializations.

In the experiments below, the dense initial matrix B^0subscript^ùêµ0\widehat{B}_{0} corresponding to Œ≥k‚üÇ‚Äã(c,Œª)superscriptsubscriptùõæùëòperpendicular-toùëêùúÜ\gamma_{k}^{\perp}(c,\lambda) given in (41) will be denoted by

B^0‚Äã(c,Œª)‚Äã=‚ñ≥Œ≥k‚ÄãP‚à•‚ÄãP‚à•T+Œ≥k‚üÇ‚Äã(c,Œª)‚ÄãP‚üÇ‚ÄãP‚üÇT.subscript^ùêµ0ùëêùúÜsuperscript‚ñ≥subscriptùõæùëòsubscriptùëÉparallel-tosuperscriptsubscriptùëÉparallel-toùëásuperscriptsubscriptùõæùëòperpendicular-toùëêùúÜsubscriptùëÉperpendicular-tosuperscriptsubscriptùëÉperpendicular-toùëá\widehat{B}_{0}(c,\lambda)\mathop{\,{\scriptstyle\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\triangle}}{{=}}}}\,\gamma_{k}P_{\parallel}P_{\parallel}^{T}+\gamma_{k}^{\perp}(c,\lambda)P_{\perp}P_{\perp}^{T}.

Using this notation, the conventional initialization B0‚Äã(Œ≥k)subscriptùêµ0subscriptùõæùëòB_{0}(\gamma_{k}) can be written as B^0‚Äã(1,0)subscript^ùêµ010\widehat{B}_{0}(1,0).

Experiment 1. In this experiment, we consider various scalings of a proposed Œ≥k‚üÇsubscriptsuperscriptùõæperpendicular-toùëò\gamma^{\perp}_{k} using LMTR. As argued in Section 3.3, it is reasonable to choose Œ≥k‚üÇsuperscriptsubscriptùõæùëòperpendicular-to\gamma_{k}^{\perp} to be large and positive; in particular, Œ≥k‚üÇ‚â•Œ≥ksuperscriptsubscriptùõæùëòperpendicular-tosubscriptùõæùëò\gamma_{k}^{\perp}\geq\gamma_{k}. Thus, we consider the parametrized family of choices Œ≥k‚üÇ‚Äã=‚ñ≥Œ≥k‚üÇ‚Äã(c,Œª)superscriptsubscriptùõæùëòperpendicular-tosuperscript‚ñ≥superscriptsubscriptùõæùëòperpendicular-toùëêùúÜ\gamma_{k}^{\perp}\mathop{\,{\scriptstyle\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\triangle}}{{=}}}}\,\gamma_{k}^{\perp}(c,\lambda) given in (41). These choices correspond to conservative strategies for computing steps in the space spanned by P‚üÇsubscriptùëÉperpendicular-toP_{\perp} (see the discussion in Section 3.3). Moreover, these can also be viewed as conservative strategies since the trial step computed using B0subscriptùêµ0B_{0} will always be larger in Euclidean norm than the trial step computed using B^0subscript^ùêµ0\widehat{B}_{0} using (41). To see this, note that in the parallel subspace the solutions will be identical using both initializations since the solution v‚à•‚àósuperscriptsubscriptùë£parallel-tov_{\parallel}^{*} does not depend on Œ≥k‚üÇsuperscriptsubscriptùõæùëòperpendicular-to\gamma_{k}^{\perp} (see (19)); in contrast, in the orthogonal subspace, ‚Äñv‚üÇ‚àó‚Äñnormsuperscriptsubscriptùë£perpendicular-to\|v_{\perp}^{*}\| inversely depends on Œ≥k‚üÇsuperscriptsubscriptùõæùëòperpendicular-to\gamma_{k}^{\perp} (see (30) and (31)).

We report results using different values of cùëêc and ŒªùúÜ\lambda for Œ≥k‚üÇ‚Äã(c,Œª)subscriptsuperscriptùõæperpendicular-toùëòùëêùúÜ\gamma^{\perp}_{k}(c,\lambda) on two sets of tests. On the first set of tests, the dense initialization was used for the entire LMTR algoirthm. However, for the second set of tests, the dense initialization was not used for the computation of the unconstrained minimizer pu‚àósuperscriptsubscriptùëùùë¢p_{u}^{*}; that is, LMTR was run using BksubscriptùêµùëòB_{k} (initialized with B0=Œ≥k‚ÄãIsubscriptùêµ0subscriptùõæùëòùêºB_{0}=\gamma_{k}I where Œ≥ksubscriptùõæùëò\gamma_{k} is given in (4)) for the computation of the unconstrained minimizer pu‚àó=‚àíBk‚àí1‚Äãgksuperscriptsubscriptùëùùë¢superscriptsubscriptùêµùëò1subscriptùëîùëòp_{u}^{*}=-B_{k}^{-1}g_{k}. However, if the unconstrained minimizer was not taken to be the approximate solution of the subproblem, B^ksubscript^ùêµùëò\widehat{B}_{k} with the dense initialization was used for computing the constrained minimizer with respect to the shape-changing norm (see line 8 in Algorithm 1) with Œ≥k‚üÇsuperscriptsubscriptùõæùëòperpendicular-to\gamma_{k}^{\perp} defined as in (41). The values of cùëêc and ŒªùúÜ\lambda chosen for Experiment 1 are found in Table 1. (See Section¬†3.4 for details on the LMTR algorithm.)

Figure¬†1 displays the performance profiles using the chosen values of cùëêc and ŒªùúÜ\lambda to define Œ≥k‚üÇsuperscriptsubscriptùõæùëòperpendicular-to\gamma_{k}^{\perp} in the case when the dense initialization was used for both the computation of the unconstrained minimizer pu‚àósuperscriptsubscriptùëùùë¢p_{u}^{*} (line 10 of Algorithm 1) as well as for the constrained minimizer with respect to the shape-changing norm (line 8 of Algorithm 1), which is denoted in the legend of plots in Figure¬†1 by the use of an asterisk (‚àó)(*). The results of Figure¬†1 suggest the choice of c=1ùëê1c=1 and Œª=12ùúÜ12\lambda=\frac{1}{2} outperform the other chosen combinations for cùëêc and ŒªùúÜ\lambda. In experiments not reported here, larger values of cùëêc did not appear to improve performance; for c<1ùëê1c<1, performance deteriorated. Moreover, other choices for ŒªùúÜ\lambda, such as Œª=34ùúÜ34\lambda=\frac{3}{4}, did not improve results beyond the choice of Œª=12ùúÜ12\lambda=\frac{1}{2}.

Figure¬†2 reports the performance profiles for using the chosen values of cùëêc and ŒªùúÜ\lambda to define Œ≥k‚üÇsuperscriptsubscriptùõæùëòperpendicular-to\gamma_{k}^{\perp} in the case when the dense initialization was only used for the computation of the constrained minimizer (line 8 of Algorithm 1) ‚Äìdenoted in the legend of plots in Figure¬†2 by the absence of an asterisk (‚àó)(*). In this test, the combination of c=1ùëê1c=1 and Œª=1ùúÜ1\lambda=1 as well as c=1ùëê1c=1 and Œª=12ùúÜ12\lambda=\frac{1}{2} appear to slightly outperform the other two choices for Œ≥k‚üÇsubscriptsuperscriptùõæperpendicular-toùëò\gamma^{\perp}_{k} in terms of both then number of iterations and the total computational time. Based on the results in Figure¬†2, we do not see a reason to prefer either combination c=1ùëê1c=1 and Œª=1ùúÜ1\lambda=1 or c=1ùëê1c=1 and Œª=12ùúÜ12\lambda=\frac{1}{2} over the other.

Note that for the CUTEst problems, the full quasi-Newton trial step is accepted as the solution to the subproblem on the overwhelming majority of problems. Thus, if the scaling Œ≥k‚üÇsuperscriptsubscriptùõæùëòperpendicular-to\gamma_{k}^{\perp} is used only when the full trial step is rejected, it has less of an affect on the overall performance of the algorithm; i.e., the algorithm is less sensitive to the choice of Œ≥k‚üÇsuperscriptsubscriptùõæùëòperpendicular-to\gamma_{k}^{\perp}. For this reason, it is not surprising that the performance profiles in Figure¬†2 for the different values of Œ≥k‚üÇsuperscriptsubscriptùõæùëòperpendicular-to\gamma_{k}^{\perp} are more indistinguishable than those in Figure¬†1.

Finally, similar to the results in the case when the dense initialization was used for the entire algorithm (Figure¬†1), other values of cùëêc and ŒªùúÜ\lambda did not significantly improve the performance provided by c=1ùëê1c=1 and Œª=12ùúÜ12\lambda=\frac{1}{2}.


Experiment 2. This experiment was designed to test whether it is advantageous to use the dense initialization for all aspects of the LMTR algorithm or just for the computation of the constrained minimizer (line 8 of Algorithm 1). For any given trust-region subproblem, using the dense initialization for computing the unconstrained minimizer is computationally more expensive than using a diagonal initialization; however, it is possible that extra computational time associated with using the dense initialization for all aspects of the LMTR algorithm may yield a more overall efficient solver. For these tests, we compare the top performer in the case when the dense initialization is used for all aspects of LMTR, i.e., (Œ≥k‚üÇ‚Äã(1,12))superscriptsubscriptùõæùëòperpendicular-to112(\gamma_{k}^{\perp}(1,\frac{1}{2})), to one of the top performers in the case when the dense initialization is used only for the computation of the constrained minimizer (line 8 of Algorithm 1), i.e., (Œ≥k‚üÇ‚Äã(1,1))superscriptsubscriptùõæùëòperpendicular-to11(\gamma_{k}^{\perp}(1,1)).

The performance profiles comparing the results of this experiment are presented in Figure 3. These results suggest that using the dense initialization with Œ≥k‚üÇ‚Äã(1,12)superscriptsubscriptùõæùëòperpendicular-to112\gamma_{k}^{\perp}(1,\frac{1}{2}) for all aspects of the LMTR algorithm is more efficient than using dense initializations only for the computation of the constrained minimizer (line 8 of Algorithm 1). In other words, even though using dense initial matrices for the computation of the unconstrained minimizer imposes an additional computational burden, it generates steps that expedite the convergence of the overall trust-region method.


Experiment 3. In this experiment, we compare the performance of the dense initialization Œ≥k‚üÇ‚Äã(1,0.5)superscriptsubscriptùõæùëòperpendicular-to10.5\gamma_{k}^{\perp}(1,0.5) to that of the line-search L-BFGS algorithm. For this comparison, we used the publicly-available MATLAB wrapper¬†[1] for the FORTRAN L-BFGS-B code developed by Nocedal et al.¬†[15]. The initialization for L-BFGS-B is B0=Œ≥k‚ÄãIsubscriptùêµ0subscriptùõæùëòùêºB_{0}=\gamma_{k}I where Œ≥ksubscriptùõæùëò\gamma_{k} is given by (4). To make the stopping criterion equivalent to that of L-BFGS-B, we modified the stopping criterion of our solver to¬†[15]:

‚Äñgk‚Äñ‚àû‚â§œµ.subscriptnormsubscriptùëîùëòitalic-œµ\left\|g_{k}\right\|_{\infty}\leq\epsilon.

The dense initialization was used for all aspects of LMTR.

The performance profiles for this experiment is given in Figure¬†4. On this test set, the dense initialization outperforms L-BFGS-B in terms of both the number of iterations and the total computational time.


Experiment 4. In this experiment, we compare LMTR with a dense initialization to L-BFGS-TR¬†[3], which computes an L-BFGS trial step whose length is bounded by a trust-region radius. This method can be viewed as a hybrid L-BFGS line search and trust-region algorithm because it uses a standard trust-region framework (as LMTR) but computes a trial point by minimizing the quadratic model in the trust region along the L-BFGS direction. In¬†[3], it was determined that this algorithm outperforms two other versions of L-BFGS that use a Wolfe line search. (For further details, see¬†[3].)

Figure¬†5 displays the performance profiles associated with this experiment on the entire set of test problems. For this experiment, the dense initialization with Œ≥k‚üÇ‚Äã(1,12)superscriptsubscriptùõæùëòperpendicular-to112\gamma_{k}^{\perp}(1,\frac{1}{2}) was used in all aspects of the LMTR algorithm. In terms of total number of iterations, LMTR with the dense initialization outperformed L-BFGS-TR; however, L-BFGS-TR appears to have outperformed LMTR with the dense initialization in computational time.

Figure¬†5 (left) indicates that the quality of the trial points produced by solving the trust-region subproblem exactly using LMTR with the dense initialization is generally better than in the case of the line search applied to the L-BFGS direction. However, Figure¬†5 (right) shows that LMTR with the dense initialization requires more computational effort than L-BFGS-TR. For the CUTEst set of test problems, L-BFGS-TR does not need to perform a line search for the majority of iterations; that is, the full quasi-Newton trial step is accepted in a majority of the iterations. Therefore, we also compared the two algorithms on a subset of the most difficult test problems‚Äìnamely, those for which an active line search is needed to be performed by L-BFGS-TR. To this end, we select, as in¬†[3], those of the CUTEst problems in which the full L-BFGS (i.e., the step size of one) was rejected in at least 30% of the iterations. The number of problems in this subset is 14. The performance profiles associated with this reduced test set are in Figure¬†6. On this smaller test set, LMTR outperforms L-BFGS-TR both in terms of total number of iterations and computational time.

Finally, Figures¬†5 and¬†6 suggest that when function and gradient evaluations are expensive (e.g., simulation-based applications), LMTR together with the dense initialization is expected to be more efficient than L-BFGS-TR since both on both test sets LMTR with the dense initialization requires fewer overall iterations. Moreover, Figure¬†6 suggests that on problems where the L-BFGS search direction often does not provide sufficient decrease of the objective function, LMTR with the dense initialization is expected to perform better.


Experiment 5. In this experiment, we compare the results of LMTR using the dense initialization to that of LMTR using the conventional diagonal initialization B0=Œ≥k‚ÄãIsubscriptùêµ0subscriptùõæùëòùêºB_{0}=\gamma_{k}I where Œ≥ksubscriptùõæùëò\gamma_{k} is given by (3). The dense initialization selected was chosen to be the top performer from Experiment 2 (i.e., Œ≥k‚üÇ‚Äã(1,12)superscriptsubscriptùõæùëòperpendicular-to112\gamma_{k}^{\perp}(1,\frac{1}{2})).

From Figure¬†7, the dense initialization with Œ≥k‚üÇ‚Äã(1,12)superscriptsubscriptùõæùëòperpendicular-to112\gamma_{k}^{\perp}(1,\frac{1}{2}) outperforms the conventional initialization for LMTR in terms of iteration count; however, it is unclear whether the algorithm benefits from the dense initialization in terms of computational time. The reason for this is that the dense initialization is being used for all aspects of the LMTR algorithm; in particular, it is being used to compute the full quasi-Newton step pu‚àósuperscriptsubscriptùëùùë¢p_{u}^{*} (see the discussion in Experiment 1), which is typically accepted most iterations on the CUTEst test set. Therefore, as in Experiment 5, we compared LMTR with the dense initialization and the conventional initialization on the subset of 14 problems in which the unconstrained minimizer is rejected at least 30% of the iterations. The performance profiles associated with this reduced set of problems are found in Figure¬†8. The results from this experiment clearly indicate that on these more difficult problems the dense initialization outperforms the conventional initialization in both iteration count and computational time.

5. Conclusion

In this paper, we presented a dense initialization for quasi-Newton methods to solve unconstrained optimization problems. This initialization makes use of two curvature estimates for the underlying function in two complementary subspaces. Importantly, this initialization neither introduces additional computational cost nor increases storage requirements; moreover, it maintains theoretical convergence properties of quasi-Newton methods. It should also be noted that this initialization still makes it possible to efficiently compute products and perform solves with the sequence of quasi-Newton matrices.

The dense initialization is especially well-suited for use in the shape-changing infinity-norm L-BFGS trust-region method. Numerical results on the outperforms both the standard L-BFGS line search method as well as the same shape-changing trust-region method with the conventional initialization. Use of this initialization is possible with any quasi-Newton method for which the update has a compact representation. While this initialization has broad applications for quasi-Newton line search and trust-region methods, its use makes most sense from a computational point of view when the quasi-Newton method already computes the compact formulation and partial eigendecomposition; if this is not the case, using the dense initialization will result in additional computational expense that must be weighed against its benefits.
